thread.title: 17 Bizarre Disney Park Urban Legends That’ll Freak You Out

author: Anna Kopsky
title: 17 Bizarre Disney Park Urban Legends That’ll Freak You Out

organizations.name: wikipedia commons / public domain wikipedia commons / fair

text:
WARNING: Some of these stories, though many are purely legend, are very disturbing. ID: 10348764 1. Someone got decapitated on Disney World’s Space Mountain. youtube.com
instagram.com
 Legend has it that a man stood up on the coaster and got his head cut off. Though this has been debunked, a man DID stand up on Disneyland’s Matterhorn in 1964, hitting his head, resulting in his death.
—Emma Rose, Facebook
ID: 10346894 2. The spirit of a little boy lurks in the Haunted Mansion in Orlando. View this image ›
forums.wdwmagic.com Cast members have said they hear him giggling and mimicking the “hurry back” lady after the ride shuts down at night.
— jessm41
ID: 10346543 3. The characters on Disneyland’s It’s A Small World ride come to life even when unplugged. disneyworld.disney.go.com
youtube.com
 Cast members often SWEAR that they see the dolls blink or appear in different places than the day before.
— lizzieh45
ID: 10348975 4. Walt Disney still haunts his Fire House apartment on Main Street at Disneyland. instagram.com
instagram.com
 An employee was cleaning the apartment shortly after Disney died, and the lamp in the window kept turning on by itself. Now the park keeps the lamp on as a tribute to Disney. People swear they occasionally see curtains moving on their own.
— aliluvv14
ID: 10346676 5. People constantly try to dump the ashes of their loved ones on Disney property. View this image ›
Disney Pixar This has supposedly become so much of a problem over the years that employees have been trained on how to handle a guest when they think remains are being scattered on property.
—Sherri Thomas, Facebook
ID: 10346508 6. The ghost of a former employee haunts Disney World’s Tower Of Terror. Wikipedia Commons / CC BY-SA 3.0 / Via en.wikipedia.org
Walt Disney Pictures
 The story goes like this: A cast member had a heart attack while loading guests onto the ride, and died in the building. His spirit haunts the ride now. Platform D is the supposed ~spooky spot~ that current employees are scared of.
— Anna Kopsky
ID: 10347998 7. The séance book in Disney World’s Haunted Mansion was originally a real, 14th century witchcraft book. View this image ›
etsy.com “Cast members had the hardest time keeping the book in the upright position. The table would often be turned over, or the book would be somewhere else. They finally had to replace it.”
—Marla Weiske, former cast member
ID: 10381772 8. The Pirates Of The Caribbean ride at Disney World is haunted by a spirit named George. youtube.com
disneyworld.disney.go.com
 “My sister’s roommate did the college program and she said that if they didn’t say ‘Good morning, George’ and ‘Goodnight, George’ at the beginning and ending of the day, respectively, the ride would shut down and they’d have problems with it all day.”
— helen adara
ID: 10382224 9. A teen drowned trying to swim from Tom Sawyer Island back to the main Disneyland Park. disneyworld.disney.go.com
 Two brothers snuck out and hid on the island until park closing. They tried swimming back to the main park, the older with the younger one on his back, but the older one went under . They found his body the next morning.
—Camille Stephens and Emeri Tompkins, Facebook
ID: 10381985 10. A ghost used to haunt the People Mover in Orlando, which would cause the ride to shut down all the time. disneyworld.disney.go.com
 “A young kid passed away on the ride by jumping from car to car. We SWEAR his spirit haunted the stock room and he’d open the emergency exit doors on the track that were locked.”
—Marla Weiske, former cast member
ID: 10381931 11. A cast member was crushed between the walls of Disneyland’s America Sings ride. Wikipedia Commons / Public Domain
Wikipedia Commons / Fair Use
 This was one of the most tragic events in Disney Park history. After the incident in 1974, the ride was rebranded to the Carousel Of Progress, and eventually shut down altogether.
—Cat Collins and Maeghan Elizabeth, Facebook
ID: 10390465 12. Disneyland has a strange ghost who can sometimes be seen running along the monorail track. instagram.com
instagram.com
 While the ghost part may not be true, a man DID die after trying to sneak into the park in 1966. Thomas Cleveland climbed a wall onto the monorail track. When spotted by security, he bolted and was hit by the monorail.
— rachelm43
ID: 10382114 13. Someone hanged themselves on It’s A Small World at Disneyland. disneyparks.disney.go.com
disneyparks.disney.go.com
 This is generally assumed to be untrue. While passengers were being evacuated for “safety concerns,” one lady took pictures. One image showed someone hanging from the ceiling above the ride, but many think it’s a prop. Take a look for yourself here (WARNING: If this photo is real, it is very disturbing.)
— basicbanana and XxBrownEyedGirlxX
ID: 10346817 14. The spirit of a man haunts Disneyland’s Space Mountain, and sometimes people see him “fall off” the ride. Wikipedia Commons / Public Domain
Disney
 “Mr. Wedway died while helping build the ride, and never got to see it finished. Sometimes he’ll ride next to you. When I worked at Disney we’d have guests screaming that there was a guy next to them on the ride who was there but fell out!”
—Marla Weiske, former cast member
ID: 10390622 15. A man died of a heart attack while riding Disney World’s Haunted Mansion because it was too terrifying. instagram.com
instagram.com
 Okay, this ended up being untrue . People speculated this was the reason for the delayed opening of the ride, but the unfortunate true reason was Walt Disney’s death in 1966.
—Jessica Coffey, Facebook
ID: 10347948 16. There’s an abandoned water park at Disney World, and allegedly music still plays over the loudspeakers. Wikipedia Commons / CC BY-SA 3.0 / Via en.wikipedia.org 's_River_Country#/media/File: Abandoned_River_Country.jpg
disboards.com
 It was called River Country, and was open from the ’70s until 2001. People who’ve documented their explorations of the park in recent years have been dealt heavy repercussions from the Disney Company.
— fernandad41
ID: 10348188 17. And Walt Disney was suspected to use Club 33 for Freemason (or, y’know, Illuminati) meetings. Public Domain
disneyparks.disney.go.com
 Many people thought Walt Disney was a member of the Freemasons, a group that, in many conspiracy theories, is believed to be run by the Illuminati, in an attempt to establish the New World Order. CREEPY.
—Rachel Louise, Facebook
